Rich,
=E7=AD=91=E7=B4=AB is read both chikushi and tsukushi.  The chiku kan=
ji is an old musical instrument and the shi kanji is the color purple (mura=
saki).  Together the kanji are an old name of Chikuzen and Chikugo and/or o=
f all of Kyushu.  Papinot lists a daimyo family name using these characters=
 and says that they were taken from the village of Chikuzen.  The name of t=
he naginata presumably refers to the place of origin.  This would have been=
 a point of contact with China in early times.  

Knutsen illustrates a few=
 examples of these in his book on polearms.  He says that they were used fr=
om the late Heian through late Muromachi.  He reads it tsukushi.  Kajihara =
reads it chikushi in his Glossary and illustrates hirazukuri and unokubigat=
a variations.

Jim




  Hi Jim, can you define Chikushi please ?.

  Rich
